title: Modeling - Rates of Change - Midpt Sum - Avg Value

content.question: A GRAPHING CALCULATOR IS REQUIRED FOR THIS QUESTION. You are permitted to use your calculator to solve an equation, find the derivative of a function at a point, or calculate the value of a definite integral. However, you must clearly indicate the setup of your question, namely the equation, function, or integral you are using. If you use other built-in features or programs, you must show the mathematical steps necessary to produce your results. Your work must be expressed in standard mathematical notation rather than calculator syntax. Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit. Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point. Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. <math alttext="The figure presents a 2 row table, with 7 columns of data. The heading for row 1 is "t, in hours," and the heading for row 2 is "R of t, in vehicles per hour ". The data in the table are as follows. Column 1. t is 0. R of t is 2935. Column 2. t is 2. R of t is 3653. Column 3. t is 4. R of t is 3442. Column 4. t is 6. R of t is 3010. Column 5. t is 8. R of t is 3604. Column 6. t is 10. R of t is 1986. Column 7. t is 12. R of t is 2201." overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtable columnlines="solid" equalrows="true" frame="solid" rowalign="center" rowlines="solid" width="auto"><mtr><mtd><mi>t</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.45em"></mspace><mtext>(hours)</mtext></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>2</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>4</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>6</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>8</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>10</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>12</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mi>R</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.45em"></mspace><mtext>(vehicles per hour)</mtext></mtd><mtd><mn>2935</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>3653</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>3442</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>3010</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>3604</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>1986</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>2201</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></math> On a certain weekday, the rate at which vehicles cross a bridge is modeled by the differentiable function <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for <math alttext="0 less than or equal to t, less than or equal to 12" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>12</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="R of t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in vehicles per hour and <math alttext="t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is the number of hours since <math alttext="7:00" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mn>7</mn><mtext>:</mtext><mn>00</mn></mrow></math> A.M. (<math alttext="t equals 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>). Values of <math alttext="R of t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> for selected values of <math alttext="t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> are given in the table above. Use the data in the table to approximate <math alttext="R prime of 5" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show the computations that lead to your answer. Using correct units, explain the meaning of <math alttext="R prime of 5" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> in the context of the problem.

The heading for row 1 is "t, in hours," and the heading for row 2 is "R of t, in vehicles per hour ". The data in the table are as follows. Column 1. t is 0. R of t is 2935. Column 2. t is 2. R of t is 3653. Column 3. t is 4. R of t is 3442. Column 4. t is 6. R of t is 3010. Column 5. t is 8. R of t is 3604. Column 6. t is 10. R of t is 1986. Column 7. t is 12. R of t is 2201." overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtable columnlines="solid" equalrows="true" frame="solid" rowalign="center" rowlines="solid" width="auto"><mtr><mtd><mi>t</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.45em"></mspace><mtext>(hours)</mtext></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>2</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>4</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>6</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>8</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>10</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>12</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mi>R</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.45em"></mspace><mtext>(vehicles per hour)</mtext></mtd><mtd><mn>2935</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>3653</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>3442</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>3010</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>3604</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>1986</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>2201</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></math> On a certain weekday, the rate at which vehicles cross a bridge is modeled by the differentiable function <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for <math alttext="0 less than or equal to t, less than or equal to 12" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>12</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="R of t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in vehicles per hour and <math alttext="t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is the number of hours since <math alttext="7:00" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mn>7</mn><mtext>:</mtext><mn>00</mn></mrow></math> A.M. (<math alttext="t equals 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>). Values of <math alttext="R of t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> for selected values of <math alttext="t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> are given in the table above. Use the data in the table to approximate <math alttext="R prime of 5" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show the computations that lead to your answer. Using correct units, explain the meaning of <math alttext="R prime of 5" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> in the context of the problem.

Use a midpoint sum with three subintervals of equal length indicated by the data in the table to approximate the value of <math alttext="the integral from 0 to 12, of, R of t, d t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mo>∫</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>12</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mi>R</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Indicate units of measure.

On a certain weekend day, the rate at which vehicles cross the bridge is modeled by the function <math alttext="H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>H</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> defined by <math alttext="H of t equals, the negative of t cubed, minus 3 times t squared, plus 288, t, plus 1300" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>H</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><msup><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup></mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn><msup><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>288</mn><mi>t</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1300</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> for <math alttext="0 less than or equal to t, less than or equal to 17" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>17</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="H of t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>H</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in vehicles per hour and <math alttext="t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is the number of hours since <math alttext="7:00" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>7</mn><mtext>:</mtext><mn>00</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> A.M. (<math alttext="t equals 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>). According to this model, what is the average number of vehicles crossing the bridge per hour on the weekend day for <math alttext="0 less than or equal to t, less than or equal to 12" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>12</mn></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> ?

For <math alttext="12 less than t, less than 17" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mn>12</mn><mo><</mo><mi>t</mi><mo><</mo><mn>17</mn></mrow></math>, <math alttext="L of t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, the local linear approximation to the function <math alttext="H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>H</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> given in part (c) at <math alttext="t equals 12" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, is a better model for the rate at which vehicles cross the bridge on the weekend day. Use <math alttext="L of t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> to find the time <math alttext="t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, for <math alttext="12 less than t, less than 17" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>12</mn><mo><</mo><mi>t</mi><mo><</mo><mn>17</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, at which the rate of vehicles crossing the bridge is <math alttext="2000" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2000</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> vehicles per hour. Show the work that leads to your answer.

topic.text: 2.3: Estimating Derivatives of a Function at a Point

skill.text: Skill 1.D: Identify an appropriate mathematical rule or procedure based on the relationship between concepts (e.g., rate of change and accumulation) or processes (e.g., differentiation and its inverse process, anti-differentiation) to solve problems.
